newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Yakovlev to produce 10 Yak-130 aircraft.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Yakovlev to produce 10 Yak-130 aircraft.

text.p: Russian aircraft maker Yakovlev said on Thursday that it had begun building 10 Yak-130 jet trainers for Russia's defence ministry.
The vice-president of Aviatsionnaya Korporatsiya Yakovlev, Arkady Gurtovoi, told Reuters the planes were being produced at its Sokol aviation plant in Nizhny Novgorod in central Russia.

Yakovlev spokesman Yuri Zasypkin, who declined to give any details of the deal, said the defence ministry had ordered the jets but there was as yet no deal on financing: "We hope the defence ministry will finance the assembly of the planes."

The ministry, which has also ordered 10 jets from Yakovlev's main competitor the Mikoyan Design Bureau, has given no exact figure for a much larger order it is expected to make but industry sources say it could be around 200.
Russian aviation experts say a Yak-130 is priced at about $8 million for internal use.
Zasypkin said the two-seater trainers would be powered by Russian-Slovak engines and have Russian avionics.

Yakovlev, one of the Soviet Union's foremost designers of military aircraft, is competing for a further order with Mikoyan, which has designed MiG fighter aircraft ranging from the MiG-1 in World War Two to the latest MiG-31 jetfighter.
Mikoyan and French aircraft designers have teamed up to offer a two-seater MiG-AT (Advanced Training) aircraft, powered by two Larzac engines made by France's Snecma and Turbomeca companies.
Sextant Avionique, a unit of Thomson-CSF, will supply the avionics. Russian newspapers say the aircraft is priced at about $10 million.
The jet can simulate complex combat missions, preparing pilots for Russian, French and U.S.-built jet fighters.
